abstract.text: An object that manages the space above your app’s custom content and either below or integrated with the window’s title bar.

inlineContent.text: object manages the controls and views that apply to the main window’s content area. Toolbars provide convenient access to the commands and features people use most often. Toolbars are also user-configurable and support the display of an interactive customization palette.

Create and configure your toolbar programmatically or using Interface Builder. Add items to the toolbar that correspond to the commands you want to feature in your window. Each item has a corresponding
object, which you use to make changes. Each toolbar manages a unique set of items, but you can synchronize the items and state of multiple toolbars by assigning the same value to their
For more information about how to use toolbars, see

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
An object that manages the space above your app’s custom content and either below or integrated with the window’s title bar.
Constants that indicate whether the toolbar displays items using a name, icon, or combination of elements.
A string value that you use to differentiate your app’s toolbars.
Constants that specify toolbar display modes.
Whether or not the user is allowed to change display modes at run time.
This functionality is independent of customizing the order of the items themselves.
Only disable when the functionality or legibility of your toolbar could not be improved by another display mode.
The user’s selection will be persisted using the toolbar’s
when
is enabled.
The default is YES for apps linked on macOS 15.0 and above.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the toolbar can add items for Action extensions.
A Boolean value that indicates whether users can modify the contents of the toolbar.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the toolbar autosaves its configuration.
The item to display in the center of the toolbar.
The set of custom items to display in the center of the toolbar.
A dictionary containing the current configuration details for the toolbar.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the toolbar’s customization palette is in use.
The object you use to customize the toolbar contents and configuration.
Posted after an item is removed from a toolbar.
A value that indicates whether the toolbar displays items using a name, icon, or combination of elements.
The toolbar’s full screen accessory view.
The maximum height of the toolbar’s full screen accessory view, in points.
The minimum height of the toolbar’s full screen accessory view.
The value you use to identify the toolbar in your app.
Creates a new toolbar with an empty identifier string.
Creates a newly allocated toolbar with the specified identifier.
Inserts an item into the toolbar at the specified index.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the toolbar is visible.
An array of itemIdentifiers that represent the current items in the toolbar.
Setting this property will set the current items in the toolbar by diffing against items that already exist.
Use this with great caution if
is enabled as it will override any customizations the user has made.
This property is key value observable.
An array containing the toolbar’s current items, in order.
Removes the item at the specified index in the toolbar.
Removes the item with matching
in the receiving toolbar. If multiple items share the same identifier (as is the case with space items) all matching items will be removed. To remove only a single space item, use
instead.
Displays the toolbar’s customization palette and handles any user-initiated customizations.
The identifier of the toolbar’s currently selected item.
Specifies the new configuration details for the toolbar.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the toolbar shows the separator between the toolbar and the main window contents.
The toolbar’s size mode.
Validates the toolbar’s visible items during a window update.
An array containing the toolbar’s currently visible items.
Posts before the toolbar adds a new item.
A set of optional methods you use to configure the toolbar and respond to changes.
A single item that appears in a window’s toolbar.
Validation of a toolbar item.
Provide users quick access to your app’s features from a toolbar and corresponding Touch Bar.

doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/App.title: Integrating a Toolbar and Touch Bar into Your App

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
